content:
ASIA-PAC

White House said it sees encouragement in Chinese President Xi’s words but added it wants to see concrete actions, while there was also a previous source report that the US rejected China's offer to cut trade deficit by USD 50bln. (Newswires)

China considering cutting import duties on cars by half. (Business Journal)

China’s government was said to have suspended over the counter options business at some brokers. (Newswires)
 

UK

EU's Michel Barnier said that the UK wants an orderly exit from the EU and that UK PM Theresa May has brought more clarity to Brexit talks. (Newswires)

 

EU

ECB's Nowotny (hawkish) stated the ECB will end bond purchases this year and that deposit rate could be lifted to -0.2% from -0.4% to start the process of rate hikes, while he added the ECB could lift Deposit Rate in September as the first phase then go on to the main Refi Rate in the second phase. (Newswires)

ECB’s spokesperson said Nowotny’s views are his own and they do not represent the ECB’s governing council view

France Finance Ministry sees 2018 GDP growth at 2%, 2019 growth at 1.9% and 2020 to 2022 growth at 1.7%. (Newswires)


FX

DXY was negative amid a firm risk tone, with flows moving out of havens (JPY and CHF) and into risk (AUD, CAD, NZD, buoyed by commodities and metals). With volatility easing slightly, carry trades – which have been battered in 2018 – were once again in vogue, helping the likes of AUDJPY and NZDJPY rally by around 1.25%. The price action in EUR was fairly narrow (range 1.2304 to 1.2377) considering the bounce after Nowotny’s comments; there were reports of offers through 1.2350 to 1.2400 which prevented price action from reaching the 1.24 level. Comments from hawkish BOE member McCafferty helped GBP rise, though 1.42 is proving elusive. EMFX action was mixed, though the RUB continued to be plagued by last week’s application of further sanctions by the US.


COMMODITIES

US API weekly crude stocks (6 Apr) +1.758M vs. Exp. -0.200M (Prev. -3.280M). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia is said to seek an oil price near USD 80/bbl and stated that oil near USD 80 would support Aramco pre-IPO, while Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih commented that OPEC is to continue stewarding market to maintain stability and that if the market needs an extension of production cuts, they'll advocate the extension. (Newswires)

Saudi Energy Ministry said Saudi Arabia plans to keep crude oil exports below 7.0mln bpd for May and that it sees Saudi Arabia’s March crude production at 9.91mln bpd, while it also reiterated its commitment to restore inventories to their normal levels. (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said long-term ties with Russia will allow OPEC to react more effectively in changing oil markets fundamentals, while reports added that it is too early for OPEC to discuss oil cut extension or replacing falling Venezuela output. (PlattsOil) Furthermore, there were earlier comments from the UAE Energy Minister that oil market rebalancing will be completed this year and that it is going better than expected regarding rebalancing the oil market. (Newswires)

EIA raised 2018 & 2019 world oil demand growth forecasts, while it cut view on 2018 production but raised view on 2019 production. (Newswires)

Canada’s Energy Minister said the government is fully supportive of the Kinder Morgan Pipeline and that it is not a matter of whether it will go ahead but rather how it will proceed. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US military officials said the US ready to attack Syria upon order from Trump which could come at any time, while there were also separate reports of US strategic bombers arriving in Cambridgeshire, UK and that USS Harry Truman strike group along with seven warships with cruise missiles have been deployed to the Mediterranean. (i24 News/Elint/Newswires)

Russia vetoed US bid at UN Security Council to present a new inquiry to lay blame for chemical weapons over the attacks in Syria, while there were also reports that Russia is jamming US drones over Syria airspace impacting military ops. (Newswires)


US

US President Trump's trade adviser Peter Navarro said the US is being taken apart by unfair trade practices and that China has a long history of Intellectual Property theft. (Newswires)

National Economic Council Deputy Director Knight is said to consider leaving the White House. (Newswires)

US Wholesale Sales MM (Feb) 1.0% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -1.1%, Rev. -1.5%). (Newswires)
US Wholesale Inventories MM (Feb) 1.0% vs. Exp. 0.9% (Prev. 1.1%)
US PPI ex Food/Energy MM (Mar) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.2%)
US PPI ex Food/Energy YY (Mar) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.5%)
US PPI Final Demand MM (Mar) 0.3% vs. Exp. 0.1% (Prev. 0.2%)
US PPI Final Demand YY (Mar) 3.0% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 2.8%)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures were buoyed by an improved risk sentiment following China President Xi’s speech overnight. There were some negative ticks in PM trade after an ECB spokesperson walked back from hawkish comments made earlier in the session by Nowotny, which saw Bunds bid, Treasuries rise in sympathy, putting pressure on the equity complex and seeing gains pared. However, while stocks were higher, futures were traversing sideways for much of the US session, with ES straddling 2650, only making moves above that area in late trade. In stock specifics, autos were bid after China’s Business Journal stated the country is considering cutting import duties on cars by half, with all major names closing green, led by Tesla (TSLA). M&A news today in pre-market saw Verifone (PAY) be acquired by Francisco Partners for $3.4bln which saw PAY rise over 51%. During trading hours WSJ reported Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) started off deal talks again, which was followed by higher spikes in both companies, as well as AT&T (T), Time Warner (TWX) and Verizon (VZ), however cell tower stocks such as Crown Castle (CCI), SBA Communications (SBAC) and American Tower (AMT) spiked lower and closed the day in the red. In late trade, tech was in focus as Facebook’s (FB) CEO Zuckerberg testified to lawmakers; there was little by way of new information, though tech and FB itself had an upside bias.  Shares traded higher throughout most the testimony but came off highs as Zuckerberg stated there will always be a free version of Facebook. SPX +1.67% at 2657, NDX +2.2% at 6616, DJI +1.8% at 24409.

Bear-flattening was the theme, with short-end yields higher by around 3bps, while the longer-end of the curve was more or less unchanged at settlement. President Xi’s speech overnight was the catalyst, helping to drive decent overnight volumes. However, as we entered the European day, the tplex was happy to range trade, with 10-year T-Notes patrolling the 120-24 to 120-29 bracket. There was some attention on the 5s30s part of the curve, which flattened to the narrowest since 2007. In the late part of the European afternoon, Treasuries were for a short while dictated by Bund action, which caught a bid after the ECB backtracked from Nowotny’s hawkish comments, made earlier in the day. However, the effect was short lived. The US sold $30bln of 3yr notes, which tailed by 0.1bps, with the yield the highest at auction since May 2007. Cover was more-or-less in line with recent averages, though indirect participation dropped to the lowest since September; dealers took the most since September 2017. This week’s $64bln of 3s/10s/30s will see a net paydown of around $12.5bln by the US Treasury, given the $74.5bln of maturities at the mid-month settlement. US 10y T-notes futs settled down 4+ ticks at 120-24+.

subject: US MARKET WRAP 10 April 2018: Easing trade war concerns buoy risk sentiment
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Stocks up, USD lower, treasuries lower, oil higher
* REAR-VIEW: President XI conciliatory comments, Hawkish Nowotny, Hawkish McCafferty, US PPI
* AHEAD: RBA Governor Lowe to speak (Overnight), China CPI (Overnight), US CPI (Weds), Fed Minutes (Weds)

* TRADE WARS: The risk tone was more constructive on Tuesday after overnight comments from China President Xi signalled that China would continue to open-up its economy. Later in the session, China’s Business Journal reported that the country was considering cutting auto import tariffs by 50% (taking to around 12.5%), which was welcomed by US President Trump, although the White House said that while it was encouraged by China’s moves, it wants to see concrete action. Trade war fears eased slightly, which helped risk assets to rally.

* GEOPOLITICS: There seems to be a growing consensus towards the idea that the US is preparing military action in Syria over the alleged use of chemical weapons by the Assad regime. The Trump administration is yet to make a final decision on action, the White House said, with an announcement likely to come within 48 hours. Elsewhere, chemical weapons watchdog OPCW said it would send a fact-finding mission to the Douma region of Syria. The US was attempting for a UN Security Council vote, though Russia vetoed the manoeuvre.

* CENTRAL BANK SPEAK: ECB hawk Nowotny on Tuesday said the ECB could lift the deposit rate by 20bps to -0.20% to begin the process of rate hikes, the first phase, before then raising the refi rate. The reaction was predictably hawkish, resulting in an ECB spokesperson to later clarify Nowotny’s comments, saying that those were his own views, not those of the Governing Council. Fed non-voter Kaplan reiterated his view of three hikes in 2018, data-dependent. Kaplan also expects inflation to gradually move towards target. BOE hawk McCafferty again called for the central bank to “not dally” over raising rates, arguing that no slack remains in the labour market, while wages have begun ticking higher.

* EQUITIES: SPX +1.67% at 2657, NDX +2.2% at 6616, DJI +1.8% at 24409 SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.15%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.53%, ENERGY (XLE): +3.42%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.28%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +1.78%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.66%, MATERIALS (XLB): +2.16%, TECH (XLK): +2.52%, TELECOMS (XTL): +2.32%, UTLITIES (XLU): -0.71%. US Equity futures were buoyed by an improved risk sentiment following China President Xi’s speech overnight. There were some negative ticks in PM trade after an ECB spokesperson walked back from hawkish comments made earlier in the session by Nowotny, which saw Bunds bid, Treasuries rise in sympathy, putting pressure on the equity complex and seeing gains pared. However, while stocks were higher, futures were traversing sideways for much of the US session, with ES straddling 2650, only making moves above that area in late trade. In stock specifics, autos were bid after China’s Business Journal stated the country is considering cutting import duties on cars by half, with all major names closing green, led by Tesla (TSLA). M&A news today in pre-market saw Verifone (PAY) be acquired by Francisco Partners for $3.4bln which saw PAY rise over 51%. During trading hours WSJ reported Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) started off deal talks again, which was followed by higher spikes in both companies, as well as AT&T (T), Time Warner (TWX) and Verizon (VZ), however cell tower stocks such as Crown Castle (CCI), SBA Communications (SBAC) and American Tower (AMT) spiked lower and closed the day in the red. In late trade, tech was in focus as Facebook’s (FB) CEO Zuckerberg testified to lawmakers; there was little by way of new information, though tech and FB itself had an upside bias.  Shares traded higher throughout most the testimony but came off highs as Zuckerberg stated there will always be a free version of Facebook.

* TREASURIES: US 10y T-notes futs settled down 4+ ticks at 120-24+ Bear-flattening was the theme, with short-end yields higher by around 3bps, while the longer-end of the curve was more or less unchanged at settlement. President Xi’s speech overnight was the catalyst, helping to drive decent overnight volumes. However, as we entered the European day, the tplex was happy to range trade, with 10-year T-Notes patrolling the 120-24 to 120-29 bracket. There was some attention on the 5s30s part of the curve, which flattened to the narrowest since 2007. In the late part of the European afternoon, Treasuries were for a short while dictated by Bund action, which caught a bid after the ECB backtracked from Nowotny’s hawkish comments, made earlier in the day. However, the effect was short lived. The US sold $30bln of 3yr notes, which tailed by 0.1bps, with the yield the highest at auction since May 2007. Cover was more-or-less in line with recent averages, though indirect participation dropped to the lowest since September; dealers took the most since September 2017. This week’s $64bln of 3s/10s/30s will see a net paydown of around $12.5bln by the US Treasury, given the $74.5bln of maturities at the mid-month settlement.

* WTI futures (May) settle $2.09 higher at $65.51/bbl; Brent (June) settled $2.39 higher at $71.04/bbl. Crude put in a solid performance on Tuesday, buoyed overnight after constructive comments from China President Xi Jinping. The complex was again lifted in the European morning after IEA’s head of oil industry and markets division suggested that steel tariffs might impact the ability of the US to produce and transport crude oil, while also arguing that OPEC+ ambitions to trim global crude inventories toward its five-year average could be achieved in 2-3 months. Ahead of this week’s monthly reports from OPEC and the IEA, EIA released its short-term energy outlook where it raised 2018 and 2019 world demand growth forecasts, cutting 2018 US production estimates, though did raise US production estimates for 2019. After the bell, the API is expected to report crude stocks to draw by 200k, Cushing stocks are seen rising by 1.5mln, gasoline stocks are expected to draw by 1.4mln, while distillates are seen unchanged. Plenty of OPEC-speak on Tuesday. Some reports suggest that Saudis are seeking oil prices near $80/bbl (recall in March the WSJ reported that OPEC was divided on the issue, with Iran seeking a price near $60 to disincentivise US shale production, while the Saudis were keen on prices near $70, it was reported in March), which helped add further upside to crude (the Saudis are also said to be keeping May exports beneath 7mln BPD). Elsewhere, the UAE energy minister said rebalancing the oil market is progressing well and will likely be complete this year.

* FOREX: DXY negative amid a firm risk tone, with flows moving out of havens (JPY and CHF) and into risk (AUD, CAD, NZD, buoyed by commodities and metals). With volatility easing slightly, carry trades – which have been battered in 2018 – were once again in vogue, helping the likes of AUDJPY and NZDJPY rally by around 1.25%. The price action in EUR was fairly narrow (range 1.2304 to 1.2377) considering the bounce after Nowotny’s comments; there were reports of offers through 1.2350 to 1.2400 which prevented price action from reaching the 1.24 level. Comments from hawkish BOE member McCafferty helped GBP rise, though 1.42 is proving elusive. EMFX action was mixed, though the RUB continued to be plagued by last week’s application of further sanctions by the US.

subject: AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 30bln 3-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EDT
content:
• The US Treasury will auction USD 62bln in 3-year notes (USD 30bln, Tuesday), 10-year bonds ($21bln, Wednesday) and 30-year bonds ($13bln, Thursday). With a total of USD 76.5bln maturing at mid-month settlement, the auction will actually pay down USD 12.5bln in the week. The bidding deadline for the auction is 1800BST (1300 eastern time) with results expected shortly after.
  • Last month’s 3-year note auction was relatively uneventful; stopping through by 0.2bps but the auction was covered just 2.94x, below the 6-auction average of 3.09x. Dealers were also left with a higher than average proportion of the issuance, but recently foreign demand has picked up, despite the increase in auction sizes.
  • TD Securities believes the 3-year point remains relatively attractive on the curve as the market remains priced for two more hikes this year and 1½ in 2019. The bank is currently long the 3-year at 2.43% and say they continue to like the trade for carry and roll.

content:
DXY

The Greenback has extended losses vs all G10 peers bar the safest-haven JPY, as the headline pair continues to encircle the 107.00 level where big option expiry interest lies through to the end of the week. The Index is just off 89.500 and session lows with the aid of firmer than forecast PPI leads ahead of Wednesday’s more pivotal CPI release and March FOMC minutes, which collectively or independently could dictate further loss of impetus below 90.000 and a test of the round number below.  

AUD/NZD/CAD

The commodity bloc continues to outperform amidst the improved risk appetite largely due to China offering to significantly reduce auto import tariffs in the initial rounds of trade war negotiations. Aud/Usd is now above 0.7750, Nzd/Usd over 0.7360 and Usd/Cad down through 1.2650 and close to the next chart support at 1.2615 with the Loonie getting additional fuel from better than expected Canadian housing starts and extended oil price gains on bullish Saudi comments.

EUR

A somewhat unexpected boost for the single currency from ECB hawk Nowotny who revealed a personal preference for hiking the depo rate by 20 bp to start the next stage of policy normalisation, before looking to tighten the main refi. Eur/Usd extended gains beyond 1.2300 through residual offers at 1.2330 and resistance at 1.2345 on the way to a circa 1.2375 peak.

 GBP

Also the beneficiary of hawkish CB rhetoric as BoE’s McCafferty said the MPC should not hang around and hike, with Cable nudging towards 1.4200.

NOK

The Krona was knocked back by weaker than forecast Norwegian CPI data, but pared losses after Norges Bank Governor Olsen reiterated post-summer tightening.

RUB/TRY

Among the major EM underperformers again amidst the Russian sanctions and geopolitical turmoil.

subject: FIXED AND FX LATEST: ECB’s Nowotny off the fence and on the offensive
content: No surprise to see a snap reaction to aggressive ‘guidance’ from known ECB hawk Nowotny, especially after relatively balanced comments earlier. His preference for a 20 bp depo hike in one fell swoop as a start before moving on to the main refi would be a significantly quicker normalisation pace than markets were factoring in and appeared to have approval for from the ECB. Hence, Bunds down sharply to 159.01 (-29 ticks vs +29 ticks at the Eurex high), Euribor strip 2.5 ticks adrift (Mar20 contract) and Eur/Usd up to circa 1.2375. Back to the charts, next support for Bunds if 159.00 gives way is last week’s low at 158.89.

reaction_details: • In an immediate reaction EURUSD went from 1.2330 to 1.2360 and there was a noted sell off in Bunds from 159.48 to 159.13 surpassing yesterday's lows
analysis_details: Markets have been pricing in a single 10bps hike in mid 2019, suggesting 20bps rate rise would signal at least two hikes (perhaps in one hit), though Nowotny does not offer details about the timing of a hike. Nowotny, who is considered a hawk, comments seem at odds with the ECB, which seemed comfortable with market pricing at the March meeting.

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: US equity futures rebounded into positive territory following comments from President Xi Jinping, paring back losses overnight seen following a probe on President Trump’s lawyer Cohen
content:
10th April 2018

To download the report, please click here

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category

  • US equity futures rebounded into positive territory following comments from President Xi Jinping, paring back losses overnight seen following a probe on President Trump’s lawyer Cohen
  • However, the latest reports suggest that the US have rejected China's offer to cut their trade deficit by USD 50bln
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI, APIs, ECB’s Visco

TRADE WARS

Chinese President Xi Jinping says China will expand opening of its economy and says reform and opening in China will definitely succeed. (Newswires)

US rejected China's offer to cut trade deficit by USD 50bln, according to a source. US asked China to stop subsidising the high-tech industry and talks were said to have stalled. (Newswires)

EU is exploring counter-measures to US aluminium tariffs, according to trade body European Aluminium. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mostly higher as the region focused on Chinese President Xi Jinping’s address at the Boao Forum which struck a conciliatory tone as he stated that cold war mentality is out of place and that China will expand the opening up of its economy. Furthermore, President Xi also vowed to lower auto tariffs and repeated the suggestion of a win-win scenario. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were underpinned as markets reacted positively to President Xi’s bullish speech with Japan helped by a weaker currency and as automakers cheered the news of the reduced tariffs. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+1.2%) conformed to the optimism, while US equity futures also recovered from the selling pressure seen from reports the FBI raided Trump lawyer Michael Cohen amid investigation related to possible bank fraud, campaign finance and the payment made to Stormy Daniels.

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3071 (Prev. 6.3114). (Newswires)

PBoC skips open market operations. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter) says that his base case is for three rate hikes. (Newswires)

ECB's Nowotny (Hawkish) says we're at an important turning point in monetary policy, adds policy must be normalised at the right time. (Newswires)

BoE's McCafferty says the BoE should not dally over raising rates modestly going forward. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

The UK is yet to put forward an alternative backstop for the Irish border issue with a lack of progress being made since March’s breakthrough in negotiations, according to sources. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

EU equities trade higher (Eurostoxx +0.20%) on the back of an improved risk sentiment throughout the market. This comes off the back of positive comments from Chinese president Xi Jinping striking a conciliatory tone and advocating the expansion of the Chinese economy. This allowed for the paring back of losses seen overnight for US equity futures that came as a result of President Trump’s lawyer Cohen being raided in relation to the Stormy Daniels case. US equities however corrected slightly in morning trade as there were mentions of a breakdown in talks between the US and China due to disagreements over the high-tech industry. Leading sectors include industrials and consumer discretionary. Outperformance has come from individual stock moves in LVMH (+5.2%) with sales figures providing positive signals for the luxury sector, lifting Christian Dior (+3.7%) and Kering (+3.1%) in sympathy. Material names have also been lifted as a result of the aforementioned improving risk sentiment positively affecting the sector due to their exposure to the tariff effects. Further individual stock news to note includes the approval of Bayer’s (+4.4%) acquisition of Monsanto which has allowed for a strong DAX in early trade (+1.4%) due to their weighting within the index. Underperformance was noted in Givaudan (-3.4%) due to uninspiring financial results

FX         

In FX, the DXY looks top-heavy again having lost momentum after its latest flirtation with the 90.000 pivot, and a breakdown of the basket reveals a distinct revival of appetite for riskier currencies. AUD has reversed relative losses and more vs the USD and NZD in wake of conciliatory remarks from Chinese President Xi on import tariffs and wider economic reforms to leap ahead of its G10 counterparts and clear several major technical obstacles in the process. AUD/USD finally soaked up offers at the 0.7700 level, including option-related supply, and the 20 DMA at 0.7719 on the way to 0.7740, while the Kiwi has crossed 0.7300 vs the Greenback as AUD/NZD holds just below 1.0550. GBP has retained its recent bid tone with the aid of hawkish comments from BoE’s McCafferty and strong May MPC hike expectations, with Cable up above 1.4160 again and EUR/GBP retesting bids/support around 0.8700. CAD/EUR/CHF are all pretty flat vs the Dollar, but with the Loonie still underpinned by NAFTA deal hopes/anticipation and breaching some chart levels after the BoC’s upbeat business survey yesterday. USD/CAD has subsequently slipped down through a Fib at 1.2723, the 55 DMA at 1.2715 and 100 DMA at 1.2691 on its way to a circa 1.2675 low before consolidating. EUR/USD has settled above 1.2300, but appears capped by offers around 1.2330 and 1.2345 resistance, while USD/CHF resides just above 0.9550. JPY The stand-out, but not outsize loser given the broad improvement in risk sentiment, as USD/JPY continues to find 107.00 alluring ahead of hefty option expiry interest at the big figure this week, plus upside technical barriers from 107.10-15 (55 DMA) to 107.50-55 (Fib). No respite for RUB or Russian assets in general, as USD/RUB extends to the upside and peaks just shy of 64.000 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have drifted down from best levels, but not before advancing further to a fresh 159.59 Eurex intraday peak (+29 ticks), with market contacts suggesting that dip-buyers were encouraged by the fact that Monday’s 159.24 session low held in (just). Moreover, a decent block purchase (7k lots) and techs looking to fill a gap (circa 159.46) exacerbated the bounce and outperformance, as Gilts slip to new Liffe lows in wake of BoE McCafferty’s characteristically hawkish comments and little of note from Haldane – 122.15 (-20 ticks) and US Treasuries remain underwater amidst neutral commentary from Fed’s Kaplan, latest PPI data and the first of this week’s auctions. Talking supply, Germany’s linker just about edged it vs the UK’s 40 year fixed tap with a decent bid/cover (nearly twice oversubscribed), but lengthy tail.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures are both trading higher, in-fitting with the global risk picture and amid lingering geopolitical tensions. This comes after US President Trump yesterday condemned the reported chemical attack in Syria and stated that the US is to make a decision on next steps in 24-48 hours; Trump refused to rule out military action. Furthermore, traders will also be mindful of the recent comments from Iran yesterday who threatened a strong response if the US pulls out of the nuclear deal and reapplies sanctions. Upcoming focus for the energy sector will likely centre around any developments on this front and tonight’s API inventory release. In metals markets, spot gold is trading with little in the way of firm direction after Xi-inspired downside overnight has been pared back during European hours. Elsewhere, aluminium prices continue to be lifted by the fallout of Russian sanctions, whilst Chinese Dalian iron ore futures were seen higher during Asia-Pac hours amid the broader risk sentiment seen overnight.

subject: DAILY US OPENING NEWS: US equity futures rebounded into positive territory following comments from President Xi Jinping, paring back losses overnight seen following a probe on President Trump’s lawyer Cohen
content:
10th April 2018

To download the report, please click here

If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category

  • US equity futures rebounded into positive territory following comments from President Xi Jinping, paring back losses overnight seen following a probe on President Trump’s lawyer Cohen
  • However, the latest reports suggest that the US have rejected China's offer to cut their trade deficit by USD 50bln
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI, APIs, ECB’s Visco

TRADE WARS

Chinese President Xi Jinping says China will expand opening of its economy and says reform and opening in China will definitely succeed. (Newswires)

US rejected China's offer to cut trade deficit by USD 50bln, according to a source. US asked China to stop subsidising the high-tech industry and talks were said to have stalled. (Newswires)

EU is exploring counter-measures to US aluminium tariffs, according to trade body European Aluminium. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mostly higher as the region focused on Chinese President Xi Jinping’s address at the Boao Forum which struck a conciliatory tone as he stated that cold war mentality is out of place and that China will expand the opening up of its economy. Furthermore, President Xi also vowed to lower auto tariffs and repeated the suggestion of a win-win scenario. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were underpinned as markets reacted positively to President Xi’s bullish speech with Japan helped by a weaker currency and as automakers cheered the news of the reduced tariffs. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+1.2%) conformed to the optimism, while US equity futures also recovered from the selling pressure seen from reports the FBI raided Trump lawyer Michael Cohen amid investigation related to possible bank fraud, campaign finance and the payment made to Stormy Daniels.

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3071 (Prev. 6.3114). (Newswires)

PBoC skips open market operations. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter) says that his base case is for three rate hikes. (Newswires)

ECB's Nowotny (Hawkish) says we're at an important turning point in monetary policy, adds policy must be normalised at the right time. (Newswires)

BoE's McCafferty says the BoE should not dally over raising rates modestly going forward. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

The UK is yet to put forward an alternative backstop for the Irish border issue with a lack of progress being made since March’s breakthrough in negotiations, according to sources. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

EU equities trade higher (Eurostoxx +0.20%) on the back of an improved risk sentiment throughout the market. This comes off the back of positive comments from Chinese president Xi Jinping striking a conciliatory tone and advocating the expansion of the Chinese economy. This allowed for the paring back of losses seen overnight for US equity futures that came as a result of President Trump’s lawyer Cohen being raided in relation to the Stormy Daniels case. US equities however corrected slightly in morning trade as there were mentions of a breakdown in talks between the US and China due to disagreements over the high-tech industry. Leading sectors include industrials and consumer discretionary. Outperformance has come from individual stock moves in LVMH (+5.2%) with sales figures providing positive signals for the luxury sector, lifting Christian Dior (+3.7%) and Kering (+3.1%) in sympathy. Material names have also been lifted as a result of the aforementioned improving risk sentiment positively affecting the sector due to their exposure to the tariff effects. Further individual stock news to note includes the approval of Bayer’s (+4.4%) acquisition of Monsanto which has allowed for a strong DAX in early trade (+1.4%) due to their weighting within the index. Underperformance was noted in Givaudan (-3.4%) due to uninspiring financial results

FX         

In FX, the DXY looks top-heavy again having lost momentum after its latest flirtation with the 90.000 pivot, and a breakdown of the basket reveals a distinct revival of appetite for riskier currencies. AUD has reversed relative losses and more vs the USD and NZD in wake of conciliatory remarks from Chinese President Xi on import tariffs and wider economic reforms to leap ahead of its G10 counterparts and clear several major technical obstacles in the process. AUD/USD finally soaked up offers at the 0.7700 level, including option-related supply, and the 20 DMA at 0.7719 on the way to 0.7740, while the Kiwi has crossed 0.7300 vs the Greenback as AUD/NZD holds just below 1.0550. GBP has retained its recent bid tone with the aid of hawkish comments from BoE’s McCafferty and strong May MPC hike expectations, with Cable up above 1.4160 again and EUR/GBP retesting bids/support around 0.8700. CAD/EUR/CHF are all pretty flat vs the Dollar, but with the Loonie still underpinned by NAFTA deal hopes/anticipation and breaching some chart levels after the BoC’s upbeat business survey yesterday. USD/CAD has subsequently slipped down through a Fib at 1.2723, the 55 DMA at 1.2715 and 100 DMA at 1.2691 on its way to a circa 1.2675 low before consolidating. EUR/USD has settled above 1.2300, but appears capped by offers around 1.2330 and 1.2345 resistance, while USD/CHF resides just above 0.9550. JPY The stand-out, but not outsize loser given the broad improvement in risk sentiment, as USD/JPY continues to find 107.00 alluring ahead of hefty option expiry interest at the big figure this week, plus upside technical barriers from 107.10-15 (55 DMA) to 107.50-55 (Fib). No respite for RUB or Russian assets in general, as USD/RUB extends to the upside and peaks just shy of 64.000 at one stage.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have drifted down from best levels, but not before advancing further to a fresh 159.59 Eurex intraday peak (+29 ticks), with market contacts suggesting that dip-buyers were encouraged by the fact that Monday’s 159.24 session low held in (just). Moreover, a decent block purchase (7k lots) and techs looking to fill a gap (circa 159.46) exacerbated the bounce and outperformance, as Gilts slip to new Liffe lows in wake of BoE McCafferty’s characteristically hawkish comments and little of note from Haldane – 122.15 (-20 ticks) and US Treasuries remain underwater amidst neutral commentary from Fed’s Kaplan, latest PPI data and the first of this week’s auctions. Talking supply, Germany’s linker just about edged it vs the UK’s 40 year fixed tap with a decent bid/cover (nearly twice oversubscribed), but lengthy tail.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent crude futures are both trading higher, in-fitting with the global risk picture and amid lingering geopolitical tensions. This comes after US President Trump yesterday condemned the reported chemical attack in Syria and stated that the US is to make a decision on next steps in 24-48 hours; Trump refused to rule out military action. Furthermore, traders will also be mindful of the recent comments from Iran yesterday who threatened a strong response if the US pulls out of the nuclear deal and reapplies sanctions. Upcoming focus for the energy sector will likely centre around any developments on this front and tonight’s API inventory release. In metals markets, spot gold is trading with little in the way of firm direction after Xi-inspired downside overnight has been pared back during European hours. Elsewhere, aluminium prices continue to be lifted by the fallout of Russian sanctions, whilst Chinese Dalian iron ore futures were seen higher during Asia-Pac hours amid the broader risk sentiment seen overnight.

Bunds: a somewhat reluctant drift down after initial resilience
content: An unexpected, albeit modest opening uptick off the Eurex open before the 10 year German benchmark begrudgingly acknowledged risk-on sentiment weighing on US Treasuries after Chinese President Xi’s keynote speech soothed trade tensions via pledges to push ahead with reforms and cut auto import tariffs significantly. Bunds are still holding up relatively well within an early 159.26-35 range around Monday’s 159.30 close, but could succumb to further downside if EU cash bourses greet the less uncompromising tone from China with open arms. On the flip-side, latest ECB rhetoric has been dovish overall amidst ongoing caution about sub-target inflation and uncertainty over the amount of slack remaining in the economy. Data-wise, Italian ip ahead, while supply comes from the Netherlands, Austria and Germany, and ECB speak via Nouy, Nowotny and Visco.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Bayer, LVMH and Telecom Italia
content:
10th April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks traded mostly higher as the region focused on Chinese President Xi Jinping’s address at the Boao Forum which struck a conciliatory tone as he stated that cold war mentality is out of place and that China will expand the opening up of its economy. Furthermore, President Xi also vowed to lower auto tariffs and repeated the suggestion of a win-win scenario. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were underpinned as markets reacted positively to President Xi’s bullish speech with Japan helped by a weaker currency and as automakers cheered the news of the reduced tariffs. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+1.2%) conformed to the optimism, while US equity futures also recovered from the selling pressure seen from reports the FBI raided Trump lawyer Michael Cohen amid investigation related to possible bank fraud, campaign finance and the payment made to Stormy Daniels.

FTSE

BAE Systems (BAE) – The co. has approved a USD 300mln sale of advanced weapons systems to Qatar. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

De La Rue (DLAR LN) – Crystal Amber targeted and acquired 2% in the co. after the Co. has lost the contract to produce US passports post-Brexit, assigned to rival Gemalto instead. (Newswires) 

Drax (DRX LN) – The power generator’s CEO said the co. could cease production at its coal plants ahead of a government imposed deadline of 2025. (Newswires)

Premier Oil (PMO LN) – Deutsche Bank has become the company’s largest shareholder at 5.22%, according to an email. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ASCENTIAL (ASCL LN) CUT FROM HOLD TO BUY AT BERENBERG

TED BAKER (TED LN) RAISED FROM NEUTRAL TO BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) – The Justice Department has approved Co.’s acquisition of Monsanto (MON) for USD 62.5bln after the two make concessions. Separately, the US FDA issued an order to restrict the sale and distribution of Co.’s Essure Device. (Newswires/WSJ)

CAC

Airbus (AIR FP) – The co. has had a tender process started by Malaysian Airlines for 20-30 widebody jets, that could surpass the deal made with Boeing (BA) agreed earlier in the year after a visit by the country’s Prime Minister last year. (Newswires)

AXA (CS FP) – Co. are to launch an overhaul of its Swiss Group Life business. (Newswires)

L’Oreal (OR FP) – Co. have been named as the preferred bidder for South Korea’s Nanda. (Newswires)

LVMH (MC FP) – Q1 sales +10% YY to EUR 10.85bln vs. exp. EUR 10.6bln, +13% on a like-for-like basis vs. expected 8.5%. (Newswires)

Air France (AF FP) – March load factor +2.7% points to 87.8%. Co. adds that strikes are to have a negative impact of around EUR 170mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ELIS SA (ELIS FP) CUT FROM TO HOLD FROM BUY AT DEUTSCHE BANK

PAN-EUROPE

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Italy’s Fund Association Assogestioni will not propose a list of candidates for the board by May 4th. Separately, most board member support the auditors’ decision on the proposal by Elliot. In addition to this the company plans to take legal action to prevent a vote-on board candidate as proposed by activist fund Elliott. (Newswires)

Saipem (SPM IM) – The co. has cut the amount of arbitration damages it is seeking from Gazprom over the south stream project by EUR 0.644bln (Newswires)

Repsol (REP SM) – The co. raises production in Q1 to 727k bpd vs. 715K bpd in Q4

BROKER MOVES

ACS (ACS SM) RAISED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

SMI

Swisscom (SCMN SW) - Italian competition watchdog says they accept Telecom Italia (TIT IM) and Fastweb (a subsidiary of Swisscom) commitments on a joint venture known as flash fibre. (Newswires)

Zurich Insurance Group (ZURN SW) – The co. will launch its share buyback program of up to 1.74mln shares on the 11th of April. All regulations have been approved for this. (Newswires)

SCANDINAVIA

US

US equity futures rebounded over the weekend from Friday trade following efforts from the US to alleviate trade concerns; US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin stated the US is willing to negotiate, but Trump is prepared to defend US interests. Healthcare and Technology led today’s US cash market, with Merck (MRK) leading the DJ closing over 5% higher as its phase 3 Keynote trial met its primary endpoint of overall survival. In M&A news sources reported Viacom (VIAB) asked CBS (CBS) to raise its merger offer by $2.8bln, with CBS still waiting to respond, however, an unnamed CBS investor has asked the company to not pay above market price for Viacom.   • Looking ahead, highlights include US PPI, APIs, ECB’s Nowotny, Visco, Fed’s Kaplan, BoE’s Haldane, McCafferty

ASIA

Asian stocks traded mostly higher as the region focused on Chinese President Xi Jinping’s address at the Boao Forum which struck a conciliatory tone as he stated that cold war mentality is out of place and that China will expand the opening up of its economy. Furthermore, President Xi also vowed to lower auto tariffs and repeated the suggestion of a win-win scenario. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) were underpinned as markets reacted positively to President Xi’s bullish speech with Japan helped by a weaker currency and as automakers cheered the news of the reduced tariffs. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+1.2%) conformed to the optimism, while US equity futures also recovered from the selling pressure seen from reports the FBI raided Trump lawyer Michael Cohen amid an investigation related to possible bank fraud, campaign finance and the payment made to Stormy Daniels. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with demand sapped as focus centred on riskier assets, although downside was also restricted amid an enhanced-liquidity auction in the long-to super-long end which saw firmer demand, while T-notes were pressured overnight as President Xi Jinping’s address spurred some safe-haven outflows.

Chinese President Xi Jinping said reform and opening up in China will definitely succeed and that China will implement major opening up steps ASAP. Chinese President Xi Jinping also commented that cold war mentality is out of place, while he announced that China will increase foreign ownership limits in the auto industry and will reduce auto product import tariffs. (Newswires)

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.3071 (Prev. 6.3114)
 

UK/EU

The UK is yet to put forward an alternative backstop for the Irish border issue with a lack of progress being made since March’s breakthrough in negotiations, according to sources. (Newswires)

UK BRC Sales Like-For-Like (Mar) Y/Y 1.4% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)

ECB’s Coeure (neutral) noted the ECB is to discuss timing of QE soon and also commented that growth outlook is not a warrant to modify current monetary policy stance. (Newswires)

ECB’s Praet (dove) said data suggests there is no need to change the ECB's outlook, while he also stated ample degree of monetary stimulus remains necessary and that inflation remains subdued. (Newswires)

EU is exploring counter-measures to US aluminium tariffs, according to trade body European Aluminium. (Newswires)
 

FX

USD/JPY and JPY-crosses rose on the back of President Xi Jinping’s speech which further doused trade war fears and resulted to safe-haven outflows, while CNH gained on the speech and AUD was also propped as a proxy for China. Elsewhere, the greenback marginally benefitted with the DXY eyeing the 90.00 level to the upside, which in turn kept overnight price action in counterparts EUR and GBP restricted.

Moody's affirmed Brazil at Ba2; but revised its outlook to Stable from Negative. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES
 

WTI crude futures gained overnight amid a positive risk tone which helped oil prices extend on the prior day’s gains of over 2% amid the backdrop of geopolitical concerns related to Syria while Iran had also threatened a strong response if the US pulls out of the nuclear deal and reapplies sanctions. Elsewhere, gold underperformed the commodities complex on safe-haven outflows, and copper gained in tandem with Chinese metal prices as the comments from China spurred risk appetite.
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump condemned the reported chemical attack in Syria and stated that the US is to make decision on next step in 24-48 hours. Furthermore, President Trump did not rule out military action, while he later stated they have a lot of military options regarding Syria and that attack response will be met forcefully. (Newswires)

US envoy to the UN Nikki Haley stated the US ‘will respond’ to Syria’s chemical attack irrespective of the UN Security Council intervention and reportedly wants the Security Council to vote on draft resolution regarding Syria chemical weapons inquiry on Tuesday.  However, there were also comments from the Russian UN envoy that the US has been warned by Moscow that military action in Syria could lead to "grave repercussions". (Newswires)

US Navy denied reports that the US Destroyer Donald Cook is heading to Syria waters. (Newswires)

North Korea Leader Kim reportedly assessed the outcome of future discussions with US at a party meeting. (KCNA)
 

US

Although Treasury yields rose modestly on Monday, curve spreads were narrower by between 1bps and 2bps at settlement. While there were lingering concerns about trade wars/geopolitics, volumes and yields were within Friday’s range. Losses were trimmed in the US afternoon, following the CBO budget and economic outlook report, which forecast higher deficits on the back of GOP spending plans. The US Treasury will sell $64bln in 3s/10s/30s this week; with $76.5bln maturing at mid-month, the Treasury will be paying down some $12.5bln. US 10-Year T-Note Futures settle 3+ ticks lower at 120-29.

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) reiterated the base case is for a total 3 hikes this year, while he also commented that China and US might be well served to turn down the heat on trade rhetoric but added that it is too early to judge how trade spat will impact the economy. (Newswires)

US President Trump lawyer Cohen was raided by the FBI under referral from Special Counsel Mueller in which the FBI seized documents relating to tax and businesses records, as well as info regarding payments to Stormy Daniels. Following these reports, US President Trump said Special Counsel Mueller's team is the most biased group of people, while replied that he thinks what is going on is a disgrace and will have to see what happens when asked if he will fire Mueller. (Newswires/CBS)

US President Trump said that we are 'fairly close' on NAFTA, while he also commented that if China hits US farmers, then the US will make it up to the farmers. (Newswires)

White House Chief of Staff Kelly could leave by the summer. (Fox Business)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: President Xi speech provided uplift for sentiment in Asia
content: Asia stocks traded mostly higher as the region focused on Chinese President Xi Jinping’s address at the Boao Forum which struck a conciliatory tone as he stated that cold war mentality is out of place and that China will expand the opening up of its economy. Furthermore, President Xi also vowed to lower auto tariffs and repeated the suggestion of a win-win scenario. As such, ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were underpinned as markets reacted positively to President Xi’s bullish speech with Japan helped by a weaker currency and as automakers cheered the news of the reduced tariffs. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.5%) and Hang Seng (+1.2%) conformed to the optimism, while US equity futures also recovered from the selling pressure seen from reports the FBI raided Trump lawyer Michael Cohen amid investigation related to possible bank fraud, campaign finance and the payment made to Stormy Daniels. Finally, 10yr JGBs were subdued with demand sapped as focus centred on riskier assets, although downside was also restricted amid an enhanced-liquidity auction in the long-to super-long end which saw firmer demand, while T-notes were pressured overnight as President Xi Jinping’s address spurred some safe-haven outflows.

content:
Asia stocks trade mostly higher as the region focuses on Chinese President Xi Jinping’s address at the Boao Forum which struck a conciliatory tone as he stated that cold war mentality is out of place and that China will expand the opening up of its economy. Furthermore, President Xi also vowed to lower auto tariffs and repeated the suggestion of a win-win scenario. As such, ASX 200 (+0.9%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) are underpinned as markets reacted positively to President Xi’s bullish speech with outperformance in Japan helped by a weaker currency and as automakers cheered the news of the reduced tariffs. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) and Hang Seng (+1.0%) conform to the optimism, while US equity futures have also recovered from the selling pressure seen from reports that FBI raided Trump lawyer Michael Cohen amid investigation related to possible bank fraud, campaign finance and the payment made to Stormy Daniels.

In FX markets, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses rose on the back of President Xi Jinping’s speech which further doused trade war fears and resulted to safe-haven outflows, while CNH gained on the speech and AUD was also propped as a proxy for China. Elsewhere, the greenback marginally benefitted with the DXY eyeing the 90.00 level to the upside, which in turn kept overnight price action in counterparts EUR and GBP restricted.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued with demand lacking as focus centres on riskier assets and with participants side-lined ahead of an enhanced-liquidity auction in the long-to super-long end later, while T-notes were pressured overnight as President Xi Jinping’s address spurred safe-haven outflows.
